fr:title.text: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In particular, the forgetful functor from an over category C/c strictly creates all connected limits that C admits and all colimits that C admits.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

It remains to show the desired adjunction. Since 1_y is terminal in C/y, a map n\to \Pi _f m in C/y induces, again by the universal property of the pullback, a unique map n\to \left [c\xrightarrow {m} x\xrightarrow {f} y^{(x\xrightarrow {f} y)}\right ] whose post-composition with m is the identity 1_f. Taking the transpose yields a map \left [f\times n\right ]\xrightarrow {g^\dag } \left [c\xrightarrow {m}x\xrightarrow {f} y\right ]. However, the product in C/y is exactly the pullback in C, so that (since mg = 1_x), this is equivalently a map f^*n\to m in C/x.
A category is connected if any pair of objects are connected by a zig-zag.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D creates limits if it reflects limits and, for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C, if FK has a limit in D, then there is a limit cone of K in C whose image under F is a limit cone of FK in D.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D preserves limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every limit cone over K, the image of this cone under F is a limit cone over FK.
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C be a category and c be an object. Then the slice category or over category C/c is:

fr:ul.fr:li: the category of elements of the contravariant hom-functor C(-, c);
the comma category (1_C\downarrow c), where *\xrightarrow {c} C is the inclusion of the point.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly it has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} c in C;
as composition, pasting along the shared morphism;
as identities, the unit laws in C.
